## Gen Z Climate Anxiety and Political Disillusionment

In a study by the BBC, 75% of young adults from the ages 16 to 25 reported themselves to have intense worry or fear about the future due to climate change. This phenomenon, known as climate anxiety, represents a significant mental health challenge for Generation Z.

Many young adults are feeling discouraged and disappointed by those in power due to the lack of proficient environmental regulations that have been put into place.(no content)Among social media users, nearly seven-in-ten Gen Zers (69%) say they felt anxious about the future the most recent time they saw content about addressing climate change.

The political disillusionment extends beyond climate issues. Gen Z is deeply disillusioned and skeptical of institutions.(no content)For many, "the economic future looks out of reach, and it seems like the government isn't doing much here at home to help you, in particular." This fuels what he calls a "scarcity, anti-system, anti-party mindset," where even traditionally left-leaning young voters are willing to turn on Democrats—or Trump—when they feel neglected.

## Cyclical History in "One Hundred Years of Solitude"

García Márquez's masterpiece explores the concept of cyclical time and repeating patterns in history. Gabriel García Márquez explored a broad range of themes in 'One Hundred Years of Solitude', primarily the tendency for man to repeat history.(no content)When Ursula sees Aureliano Triste planning the railroad, much like his grandfather Jose Arcadio planned Macondo's growth, it "confirmed her impression that time was going in a circle."(no content)Márquez makes the case that because of the cyclical nature of reality, the past, present, and futures are all the same.(no content)Throughout One Hundred Years of Solitude, characters cannot break free of their family's behavioral patterns: instead, they find themselves trapped within fates that echo their family history. Characters are haunted by the decisions they've made, but also by the decisions their ancestors have made, even becoming confused by the difference between past, present, and future.

## Modern Parallels and Contemporary Relevance

The themes in García Márquez's novel resonate with contemporary concerns. This again shows the real life cyclical history that has happened. Recent history also shows that the repetitive features of One Hundred Years of Solitude have not been broken.(no content)In an era marked by political upheavals and the Cold War's ideological divides, the story resonated for its portrayal of Latin America's tumultuous history, from colonial times to modernity. It mirrored the continent's struggles with imperialism, civil unrest, and the quest for identity, making it incredibly relevant to its contemporary readers.

The cyclical nature of the novel reflects broader patterns that Generation Z may be experiencing today - feeling trapped in systems they didn't create, facing repetitive crises (climate change, economic uncertainty, political dysfunction), and struggling with a sense that despite technological progress, fundamental human and societal problems persist.

The cyclical nature of life and history is one of the most prominent themes in One Hundred Years of Solitude. Each generation of the Buendía family seems destined to repeat the mistakes of the past... As one generation faces disillusionment, the next is born into similar circumstances, indicating that history has a tendency to repeat itself.

This mirrors how many young people today feel they're inheriting unresolved crises from previous generations while being expected to solve problems they didn't create - much like the Buendía family's endless cycle of solitude and repeated patterns.
